report.options: --- audit: parameter_values: true exclude_vector_patterns: [] include_vector_patterns: [] link_templates: [] links: true forms: true cookies: true jsons: true xmls: true ui_forms: true ui_inputs: true browser_cluster: local_storage: {} wait_for_elements: {} pool_size: 6 job_timeout: 25 worker_time_to_live: 100 ignore_images: false screen_width: 1600 screen_height: 1200 datastore: report_path: token: 0fab5abc8b50e0bfb8fdae93cb0b33ba http: user_agent: Arachni/v1.4 request_timeout: 10000 request_redirect_limit: 5 request_concurrency: 20 request_queue_size: 100 request_headers: {} response_max_size: 500000 cookies: {} authentication_type: auto input: values: name: arachni_name user: arachni_user usr: arachni_user pass: 5543!%arachni_secret txt: arachni_text num: '132' amount: '100' mail: arachni@email.gr account: '12' id: '1' default_values: name: arachni_name user: arachni_user usr: arachni_user pass: 5543!%arachni_secret txt: arachni_text num: '132' amount: '100' mail: arachni@email.gr account: '12' id: '1' without_defaults: true force: false scope: redundant_path_patterns: {} dom_depth_limit: 5 exclude_file_extensions: [] exclude_path_patterns: [] exclude_content_patterns: [] include_path_patterns: [] restrict_paths: [] extend_paths: [] url_rewrites: {} session: {} checks: - sql_injection - sql_injection_differential - sql_injection_timing - no_sql_injection - no_sql_injection_differential platforms: [] plugins: {} no_fingerprinting: false authorized_by: url: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/

issue.name: Blind SQL Injection (differential analysis)
issue.description:
Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.
To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself.
An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.
The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.
This injection was detected as Arachni was able to inject specific SQL queries, that if vulnerable, result in the responses for each injection being different. This is known as a blind SQL injection vulnerability.
issue.remedy_guidance:
The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.
Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

check.name: Blind SQL Injection (differential analysis)
check.description: It uses differential analysis to determine how different inputs affect behavior of the web application and checks if the displayed behavior is consistent with that of a vulnerable application.
check.author: Tasos "Zapotek" Laskos <tasos.laskos@arachni-scanner.com>

issue.name: SQL Injection
issue.description:
Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.
To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself.
An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.
The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.
This injection was detected as Arachni was able to cause the server to respond to the request with a database related error.
issue.remedy_guidance:
The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.
Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

check.name: SQL Injection
check.description: SQL injection check, uses known SQL DB errors to identify vulnerabilities.
check.author: Tasos "Zapotek" Laskos <tasos.laskos@arachni-scanner.com>

issue.signature: You have an error in your SQL syntax;
issue.proof: You have an error in your SQL syntax;

issue.name: SQL Injection
issue.description:
Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.
To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself.
An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.
The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.
This injection was detected as Arachni was able to cause the server to respond to the request with a database related error.
issue.remedy_guidance:
The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.
Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

check.name: SQL Injection
check.description: SQL injection check, uses known SQL DB errors to identify vulnerabilities.
check.author: Tasos "Zapotek" Laskos <tasos.laskos@arachni-scanner.com>

issue.name: Blind SQL Injection (timing attack)
issue.description:
Due to the requirement for dynamic content of today's web applications, many rely on a database backend to store data that will be called upon and processed by the web application (or other programs). Web applications retrieve data from the database by using Structured Query Language (SQL) queries.
To meet demands of many developers, database servers (such as MSSQL, MySQL, Oracle etc.) have additional built-in functionality that can allow extensive control of the database and interaction with the host operating system itself.
An SQL injection occurs when a value originating from the client's request is used within a SQL query without prior sanitisation. This could allow cyber-criminals to execute arbitrary SQL code and steal data or use the additional functionality of the database server to take control of more server components.
The successful exploitation of a SQL injection can be devastating to an organisation and is one of the most commonly exploited web application vulnerabilities.
This injection was detected as Arachni was able to inject specific SQL queries, that if vulnerable, result in the responses for each request being delayed before being sent by the server. This is known as a time-based blind SQL injection vulnerability.
issue.remedy_guidance:
The only proven method to prevent against SQL injection attacks while still maintaining full application functionality is to use parameterized queries (also known as prepared statements). When utilising this method of querying the database, any value supplied by the client will be handled as a string value rather than part of the SQL query.
Additionally, when utilising parameterized queries, the database engine will automatically check to make sure the string being used matches that of the column. For example, the database engine will check that the user supplied input is an integer if the database column is configured to contain integers.

check.name: Blind SQL injection (timing attack)
check.description: Blind SQL Injection check using timing attacks.
check.author: Tasos "Zapotek" Laskos <tasos.laskos@arachni-scanner.com>

vector.source: <form action="search.php?test=query" method="post"> <label> search art </label> <input name="searchFor" type="text" size="10"> </input> <input name="goButton" type="submit" value="go"> </input> </form>

remark.text: Delays (in seconds) used for each phase: 4.0, 8.0, 16.0, 16.0
Response times (in seconds) for control requests prior to phases 2, 3, 4: 0.203, 4.328, 4.875
Response times (in seconds) for stabilization requests after each phase: 1.422, 2.594, 3.656, 14.687
